prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
SENSITIVITY REQUIREMENTS AND CORRELATOR SETUP The primary goal of this proposal is to detect cold dust emission over a sample of thirteen old-living disks in Lupus. We request two bands: band 3 and band 6 for performing dust emission measurements and grain growth studies.
A spatial resolution of 1" in both bands is enough to resolve dust and gas structures of the order of a hundred AU at the distance of Lupus (~140 pc). Our aim is to have a detection limit of dust emission below 1 Mjup at a signal-to-noise ratio better than 6. Considering a typical Tdust=20 K and a dust opacity law with exponent beta=1.5 , an rms of 0.1 mJy would be enough to achieve our goals in a short amount of time.
For band 6 we aim to use three spectral windows to observe continuum, with two of them in TDM mode, and a third one using a bandwidth of 1.875GHz and a resolution in velocity of 0.8 km/s after Hanning smoothing, which will be strategically placed to cover 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1) as a completely secondary goal (will allow us to get possible serendipitous detections of compact molecular gas emission at a velocity resolution of ~0.8 km/s (after Hanning smoothing). The fourth spectral window in band 6 will be centered at the frequency of CO(2-1).
Since our main goal is to detect dust emission, we will attach our time estimation to the time needed for detecting the dust component. The expected time on source (few minutes)This will provide an rms of ~0.3 K for line measurements, enough to detect gas at the expected intrinsic brightness temperature of 3 K or more.
IMAGING: For this source we require one individual pointing per source.
CALIBRATION No special calibration is needed.

SENSITIVITY REQUIREMENTS AND CORRELATOR SETUP The primary goal of this proposal is to detect cold dust emission over a sample of thirteen old-living disks in Lupus. We request two bands: band 3 and band 6 for performing dust emission measurements and grain growth studies.
For BAND 3: A spatial resolution of 1" is enough to resolve dust and gas structures of the order of a hundred AU at the distance of Lupus (~140 pc). Our aim is to have a detection limit of dust emission below 1 Mjup at a signal-to-noise ratio better than 6. Considering a typical Tdust=20 K and a dust opacity law with exponent beta=1.5 , an rms of 0.1 mJy would be enough to achieve our goals in a short amount of time.
We will use three spectral windows for continuum measurements (TDM mode), and a fourth spectral window to observe gas emission from CO (1-0) at a velocity resolution of 0.3 km/s after Hanning smoothing. This is enough to resolve the kinematics of disks, expected to be ~10 km/s.
Since our main goal is to detect dust emission, we will attach our time estimation to the time needed for detecting the dust component. The expected time on source (few minutes). This will provide an rms of ~0.4 K for line measurements, enough to detect gas at the expected intrinsic brightness temperature of 3 K or more.
IMAGING: For this source we require one individual pointing per source.
CALIBRATION No special calibration is needed.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Current planet formation models are largely based on the observational constraint that protoplanetary discs have lifetime ~3 Myr. Using a new robust method to identify PMS stars through their photometric excess in the H$\alpha$ band, we have studied with the WFPC2, ACS and WFC3 imagers on board of HST and WFI at the 2.2m (La Silla) the PMS population in several starburst clusters in the Galaxy and in the Small and Large Magellanic Clouds. We found a spread of ages (0.5 to 20 Myr) of PMS stars and that accretion from circumstellar discs continues well past 10 Myr. Recently, a population of candidate old living disks has been found is LupusIII. We propose to use ALMA to perform a follow up of this disks in this close-by ($\sim140$pc) Lupus III star forming region and characterize properties of the dust (and gas) content . Confirming whether the long timescales of circumstellar discs are common will have profound implications for theories of protoplanetary discs evolution and of star clusters formation.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
